study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess psychological distress in Italian nursing students and explore its relationship with dispositional mindfulness, emotional regulation difficulties, and empathy.
results_summary: Higher dispositional mindfulness was associated with lower psychological distress, while emotional regulation difficulties and empathic personal distress were positively linked to perceived stress. No gender differences in stress levels were found, but senior students showed lower distress than junior students.
population_specificity: Undergraduate nursing students from five teaching hospitals in northern Italy (n=622).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of mindfulness-based therapies, such as meditation and yoga, on clinical and endoscopic disease activity and overall quality of life in patients with inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD).
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based therapies did not consistently demonstrate benefits in clinical or endoscopic disease activity in IBD but may improve overall quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of parent-implemented Early Start Denver Model (P-ESDM) alone versus P-ESDM combined with mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) on parent functioning in caregivers of children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: Both groups showed improvements in parent stress during active treatment, but the P-ESDM plus MBSR group demonstrated sustained benefits at follow-up, suggesting long-term impacts on parent stress. The study highlights the potential of low-intensity stress-reduction strategies for caregivers.
population_specificity: Caregivers of children under 36 months old diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of conducting a larger RCT comparing Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) and a locally-developed stress reduction intervention (LSR) in a Danish municipal health care setting.
results_summary: The study found that MBSR appeared superior to LSR, with acceptable recruitment and retention rates. Participants showed a clear need for stress reduction based on mental health scores, and follow-up loss was evenly distributed.
population_specificity: 71 adults with stress-related problems in a Danish municipal health care setting (59% female, median age 44).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of the eHealth toolkit OWLCP in reducing pain impact and pain-related outcomes among chronic pain patients.
results_summary: The study found reductions in depression, pain interference, and average pain impact, along with increased pain self-efficacy and a 13% reduction in opioid use.
population_specificity: Low-income, racially diverse patients with chronic pain (91% female, 37% Black, 16% Hispanic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and initial efficacy of Mindfulness-Based Relapse Prevention (MBRP) as an adjunct to standard relapse prevention treatment for smoking cessation.
results_summary: MBRP was found feasible and acceptable, with participants reporting increased mindfulness and reduced craving. While initial abstinence rates were lower in the MBRP group at Week 4, the MBRP group maintained higher abstinence rates by Week 24 compared to the standard treatment group.
population_specificity: Smokers in the maintenance phase of treatment (n = 86).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a single-module, fully automated internet-based behavioral activation (iBA) intervention for depression against an active control and a nonactive control group.
results_summary: The study found no significant short-term efficacy of the iBA intervention for depression compared to control groups, though long-term effects were suggested as possible through changes in secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: 104 people with at least mild depressive symptoms (Patient Health Questionnaire-9 score >4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine global publication trends and the development of interventions, including mindfulness, for treating depression.
results_summary: The study found an increase in papers related to non-pharmacological treatments like mindfulness for improving the quality of life in depressed patients, though research in low-middle income countries lagged behind high-income countries.
population_specificity: Patients with depression globally, with noted disparities between low-middle income and high-income countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of mindfulness and yoga as complementary health approaches for improving quality of life and lung function in children and adolescents with asthma.
results_summary: Mindfulness interventions showed potential in reducing stress and anxiety and improving quality of life and lung function in adolescents with asthma, though only two studies focused on mindfulness.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with asthma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a mindfulness-based workshop could reduce racial bias and improve provider-patient interactions during racially charged medical encounters.
results_summary: The intervention improved observed emotional rapport and responsiveness, reduced microaggressions, and enhanced self-reported attitudes and working alliance with Black standardized patients.
population_specificity: Medical students and recent graduates (n=25).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence on whether stress-relieving strategies like mindfulness regulate cortisol secretion and promote brain health.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that mindfulness and other stress-relieving activities can reduce stress and enhance well-being, potentially regulating cortisol secretion and improving brain health. However, specific efficacy data for mindfulness alone is not detailed.
population_specificity: Healthy populations and potential applications for clinical disorders (e.g., Parkinson's disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize existing data on the lasting psychological effects of classic psychedelics, including mindfulness, by reviewing 34 experimental studies with follow-up periods of at least two weeks.
results_summary: The study found enduring changes in mindfulness, along with other psychological factors like personality, depression, and spirituality, linked to mystical experiences, connectedness, and emotional breakthroughs. Limited aversive side effects were noted when proper screening, preparation, and supervision were in place.
population_specificity: Human subjects in contemporary experimental studies involving classic psychedelics.
effective_dosage: Not specified (psilocybin was the most frequently administered drug, but exact dosages are not provided).
study_duration: Follow-up latencies of at least two weeks (intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of mindfulness as a behavioral intervention for managing pain and psychiatric symptoms in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness, along with other behavioral interventions, is a first-line treatment for psychiatric and chronic pain disorders in IBD patients, though clinical trials specifically examining its efficacy in this population are limited.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) experiencing trauma, post-traumatic stress symptoms, and chronic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the accuracy of a wearable sensor in detecting and differentiating self-reported craving and stress episodes in individuals with substance use disorders, and to evaluate the acceptability of sensor-based monitoring.
results_summary: The study found that wearable sensors could differentiate stress vs. non-stress states (74.5% accuracy), craving vs. no-craving (75.7% accuracy), and craving vs. stress (76.8% accuracy). Participants reported positive perceptions, including increased mindfulness and connectedness, though barriers like interference with daily wear items and stigma were noted.
population_specificity: Adults enrolled in an outpatient treatment program for substance use disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of incorporating Yoga into the treatment of eating disorders, specifically bulimia nervosa and binge eating disorder.
results_summary: Compared to waitlist controls, Yoga participants experienced reductions in binge eating frequency, emotional regulation difficulties, and self-criticism, along with increases in self-compassion and state mindfulness skills. The results suggest Yoga may be beneficial, but further rigorous research is needed.
population_specificity: 53 women with symptoms of bulimia nervosa and binge eating disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of the Caregiver Support Intervention (CSI) in improving parenting skills and psychosocial wellbeing among refugee caregivers in high-adversity settings.
results_summary: The study evaluated CSI's impact on parenting quality, parental warmth, harsh parenting, and child psychosocial wellbeing, with outcomes measured at baseline, post-intervention, and 3-month follow-up. Results suggest potential benefits, but final efficacy data are pending completion of the trial.
population_specificity: Syrian refugee caregivers of children aged 3-12 years in North Lebanon.
effective_dosage: Nine-session psychosocial group intervention (frequency not specified).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated (follow-up at 3 months post-intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify biological mechanisms or biomarkers measured in nonpharmacologic stress reduction interventions for chronic pain and evaluate whether these interventions led to changes in pain outcomes or biomarkers.
results_summary: The review found that mindfulness-based stress reduction was among the interventions studied, but only three of the 13 included studies demonstrated an association between biomarkers and pain-related outcomes, highlighting the complexity of stress-pain relationships.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic pain conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence base for mindfulness programs, particularly focusing on the challenges and gaps in understanding its efficacy and implementation, especially with children.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the inadequate scholarly evidence for mindfulness benefits, noting varying definitions, insufficient scientific testing, and developmental challenges in children. It suggests the need for better research and practical guidance for professionals working with children.
population_specificity: Children and general populations (adults implied but not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and acceptability of a personalized psychological treatment for anxiety in autistic adults, which included Mindfulness as one of the modular approaches.
results_summary: The study did not provide specific results for Mindfulness alone but evaluated a combined modular approach, including Mindfulness, for anxiety in autistic adults. The overall intervention showed promise in addressing anxiety, but individual component efficacy was not detailed.
population_specificity: Autistic adults with clinically diagnosed anxiety.
effective_dosage: Not specified (up to 12 individualized therapy sessions, with Mindfulness as one potential component).
study_duration: Not specified (intervention duration depended on individual needs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of an online mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) in reducing pregnancy distress and explore potential working mechanisms.
results_summary: The study is a randomized controlled trial designed to evaluate the impact of an online MBI on pregnancy distress, mindfulness skills, rumination, and self-compassion, with results pending completion.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with elevated levels of pregnancy distress.
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but follow-up assessments occur at 8 weeks post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness meditation on reducing anxiety in nursing students.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant reduction in trait anxiety in the intervention group, while state anxiety decreased but not significantly. Anxiety increased significantly in the comparison group, though progression differences between groups were not significant.
population_specificity: Nursing students (n = 49)

study_goal: To assess the acceptability and feasibility of integrating a pre-existing mindfulness meditation smartphone app into clinical practice for women with chronic pelvic pain (CPP) and to inform the design of a future randomized clinical trial.
results_summary: The app was used infrequently by participants, with prestudy volunteers being enthusiastic but clinic-recruited patients less positive due to barriers like lack of motivation and technological familiarity. Staff expressed concerns about the need for additional support and organizational backing for successful implementation.
population_specificity: Women with chronic pelvic pain lasting ≥6 months, with access to a smartphone or personal computer and basic English understanding.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mindfulness and device-guided slow breathing interventions versus a control group in improving awareness, reducing hyperactivity, inattention, and stress among students with attention problems and/or learning disabilities.
results_summary: Mindfulness practice improved present-moment awareness and reduced hyperactivity and inattention, while both mindfulness and device-guided breathing were associated with stress reduction, as indicated by galvanic skin response changes in the control group.
population_specificity: Seventy-three higher education students (average age 25.76) with attention problems and/or learning disabilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore pedagogical principles and qualitative synthesis of mindfulness training (MT) in health and social care education, focusing on teaching setup, delivery, and outcomes.
results_summary: The review found variability in MT definitions, facilitator training, and delivery methods, with most studies involving small, self-selected female cohorts. Benefits included stress reduction, self-awareness, peer cohesion, and improved patient attention, but formal assessment was lacking.
population_specificity: Health and social care students, predominantly female and self-selected.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of a randomized trial testing a modified mindfulness meditation smartphone app for women with chronic pelvic pain, comparing it to an active control (muscle relaxation) and usual care.
results_summary: The study found extremely low adherence to the mindfulness app (mean use: 1.8 days), with clinical outcomes showing no significant benefit over usual care or active control. Despite successful recruitment and follow-up rates, the low engagement suggested a definitive trial with this app was not warranted.
population_specificity: Women over 18 with chronic pelvic pain (organic or non-organic) lasting ≥6 months, recruited from UK gynaecology clinics.
effective_dosage: Daily mindfulness meditation via app (specific duration/frequency not detailed beyond 60-day intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) on anxiety and self-efficacy in coping with childbirth among pregnant women.
results_summary: MBSR significantly reduced anxiety in pregnant women but did not significantly impact self-efficacy in coping with childbirth. The intervention group showed a notable decrease in anxiety scores compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 70 pregnant women in Abyek city, Qazvin province, Iran.
effective_dosage: 6 MBSR training sessions (specific duration per session not mentioned).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied to span the duration of the 6 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term effectiveness and acceptability of a mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) compared with relaxation training (RT) in reducing emotional exhaustion among medical students.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a plan to evaluate emotional exhaustion, anxiety-depressive symptoms, suicidality, and other secondary outcomes at multiple time points, but results are not yet reported as it is a protocol description.
population_specificity: Fourth and fifth-year medical students from nine French universities.
effective_dosage: 8-week program with one group class per week and daily at-home exercises.
study_duration: 8 weeks, with follow-up evaluations at 6 and 12 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze global publication trends and content regarding the impacts of mind-body therapies (MBT), including Mindfulness, on quality of life (QoL) across different patient groups.
results_summary: The study found an exponential increase in MBT research, with Mindfulness being a common theme. MBT showed promise in improving QoL and was incorporated into health services, particularly for chronic diseases.
population_specificity: Various patient groups and the general population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of VR-based mindfulness/meditation sessions in improving post-operative pain control, narcotic utilization, and patient satisfaction in the perioperative setting.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in post-operative pain scores, narcotic utilization, or satisfaction between VR and standard care groups. However, VR was well-tolerated, associated with high patient satisfaction, and feasible to implement, with most participants completing all sessions and reporting low pain, anxiety, and nausea during use.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing minimally invasive foregut surgery at a single institution.
effective_dosage: Six VR meditation/mindfulness sessions (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of mindfulness-based interventions among U.S. military personnel with chronic pain, focusing on pain intensity, depressive symptoms, and physical functioning.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based interventions showed a reduction in pain intensity and improvement in physical functioning, but no statistically significant effect on depressive symptoms. The effect sizes were moderate for pain and physical functioning.
population_specificity: U.S. military personnel living with chronic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of suppression and acting with awareness (a facet of mindfulness) on craving in individuals with substance use disorders.
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness (acting with awareness) may reduce craving, while suppression is associated with increased craving. The abstract implies a potential benefit of mindfulness in managing cravings, but full results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Individuals with substance use disorders (SUDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy adapted for IBS (MBCT-IBS) on symptom reduction and quality of life, as well as investigate its therapeutic mechanisms.
results_summary: The MBCT-IBS group reported significantly greater reductions in IBS symptoms and improvements in quality of life compared to the control group, with potential mechanisms involving reduced maladaptive illness cognitions and changes in self-processing.
population_specificity: 67 female patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the importance of screening for adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) in pediatric settings and the role of mindfulness as part of anticipatory guidance for healthy development.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on mindfulness's effects but emphasizes its inclusion as part of essential guidance for addressing ACEs.
population_specificity: Children under 18 years and their families in pediatric medical settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent findings on fibromyalgia treatments, including mindfulness-based interventions, to assess their potential benefits.
results_summary: The abstract mentions mindfulness-based interventions as one of the complementary therapies explored for fibromyalgia, suggesting potential efficacy alongside other treatments like hyperbaric oxygen and ozone therapy. However, specific results for mindfulness are not detailed.
population_specificity: Fibromyalgia patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish optimal protocols for a future trial assessing mindfulness-based resilience training's effects on physiological, behavioral, and psychological outcomes in law enforcement officers.
results_summary: The study focused on feasibility and optimization of procedures for recruitment, intervention fidelity, and outcome measures, but did not report specific efficacy results for mindfulness training. The long-term goal is to reduce violence and improve resilience and mental health among law enforcement officers.
population_specificity: Law enforcement officers (LEOs) exposed to high stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) for psychological distress, fear of cancer recurrence, fatigue, spiritual well-being, and quality of life in Japanese ambulatory patients with Stage I-III breast cancer.
results_summary: MBCT significantly improved psychological distress, fear of cancer recurrence, fatigue, spiritual well-being, and quality of life compared to the control group, with effects maintained four weeks post-intervention.
population_specificity: Japanese ambulatory patients with Stage I-III breast cancer.
effective_dosage: Eight-week MBCT intervention (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immediate and long-term effects of non-pharmacological interventions, including mindfulness meditation, on fatigue in community-dwelling older adults.
results_summary: Non-pharmacological interventions, including mindfulness meditation, showed significant immediate positive effects on fatigue, but no lasting effect. Both physical and cognitive/mental interventions effectively alleviated fatigue.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults experiencing fatigue.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) is non-inferior to cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) in reducing tinnitus distress in chronic tinnitus patients at 12 months follow-up.
results_summary: The study expects MBCT to be non-inferior to CBT for tinnitus distress and most secondary outcomes, with a significant difference favoring MBCT for mindfulness awareness. Results will be published post-trial.
population_specificity: Chronic tinnitus patients (≥32 on the Tinnitus Functional Index, suffering for at least 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the physical, behavioral, and psychosocial effects of a newly developed mindfulness program for older adults with type 2 diabetes relocating to long-term care facilities.
results_summary: The mindfulness program significantly improved glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels, reduced relocation stress, and alleviated depression in participants. The results suggest positive effects of mindfulness for older people with diabetes transitioning to long-term care.
population_specificity: Older adults with type 2 diabetes relocating to long-term care facilities in Southern Taiwan.
effective_dosage: Not specified (program included meditations, education, and exercise techniques over 9 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) with pharmacotherapy (escitalopram) for treating anxiety disorders.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a non-inferiority trial design but does not report results; it aims to evaluate symptom severity, tolerability, and satisfaction between MBSR and medication.
population_specificity: Individuals with diagnosed anxiety disorders (generalized anxiety disorder, social anxiety disorder, panic disorder, and agoraphobia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a theoretical model integrating mindfulness into an existing cognitive behavioral intervention (Coping Power) to address reactive aggression in high-risk children and improve emotionally charged parent-child interactions.
results_summary: The study proposed that mindfulness could positively impact the mechanisms of reactive aggression (attentional, cognitive, behavioral, and emotional dysregulation) and enhance mindful parenting by improving emotional self-regulation and presence. The model suggests mindfulness integration may optimize existing interventions for greater effectiveness.
population_specificity: High-risk children exhibiting reactive aggression and their parents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a virtual mind-body group intervention (RY-NF) improved resiliency factors (mindfulness, coping, gratitude, optimism, and social support) in adolescents with neurofibromatoses compared to a health education control group (HE-NF).
results_summary: Participation in RY-NF led to greater pre-to-post improvements in gratitude and sustained improvements in several resiliency factors at 6-month follow-up, suggesting the intervention was effective in enhancing resilience.
population_specificity: Adolescents (aged 12-17) with neurofibromatoses (NF1 and NF2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the recovery journeys of individuals with recurrent depression who participated in mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) alongside antidepressant medication, focusing on their treatment experiences and outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that recovery journeys in recurrent depression are unique and influenced by beliefs about depression, personal agency, acceptance, quality of life, experiences with medication, and interactions with healthcare providers. MBCT was adapted to support antidepressant tapering and discontinuation, with themes highlighting individualized and collaborative care.
population_specificity: Adults with a history of recurrent depression in primary care settings (urban and rural UK).
effective_dosage: Eight weekly group sessions, plus four refresher sessions over the following year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding a 9-week mindful yoga intervention (MYI) to treatment as usual (TAU) improves outcomes for young women with major depressive disorder (MDD) and explores underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, with baseline data collected from 171 females (88 in MYI group), but final results on efficacy and mechanisms are pending postintervention and follow-up assessments.
population_specificity: Young females aged 18-34 with MDD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness as an intervention for improving sexual dysfunction in women with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness was one of the interventions that improved some primary outcomes of sexual dysfunction, though specific details on its efficacy relative to other interventions were not provided.
population_specificity: Women with multiple sclerosis experiencing sexual dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of a couple-based meditation (CBM) program targeting symptom and well-being outcomes in brain tumor patients and their partners.
results_summary: The CBM program showed significant improvements in cognitive and general disease symptoms, relationship well-being, and compassion for patients, with medium-to-large effect sizes. No significant benefits were observed for partners.
population_specificity: Patients with primary and metastatic brain tumors and their partners.
study_duration: 4 weeks (with follow-ups at 6 and 12 weeks post-baseline).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and acceptability of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) in young adult cancer patients and assess its impact on physical, social, and emotional functioning.
results_summary: The study found that MBSR was feasible and acceptable, with 72%-78% of participants reporting it as logical and useful for wellbeing. MBSR participants showed improved patient-reported outcomes compared to the waitlist control group.
population_specificity: Young adult cancer patients at a large Midwestern comprehensive cancer center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and stress-related outcomes of a 6-week mindfulness-based intervention (FOCUS) for caregivers of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HCT) cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that FOCUS was highly feasible and acceptable, with significant improvements in mindfulness, post-traumatic growth, and general mental health, along with significant reductions in negative affect.
population_specificity: Caregivers of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HCT) cancer patients (N = 21; 76% female; mean age = 57.43).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindful Awareness Practice (MAP) improved biomarker levels related to stress, inflammation, and neuroplasticity in older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: MAP significantly reduced high-sensitivity c-reactive protein (hs-CRP) levels at 9 months, particularly in females and those with amnestic-MCI. Males showed significant decreases in interleukin (IL)-6 and IL-1β levels at 3 months, though improvements were not sustained at 9 months.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults aged 60+ diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
study_duration: 3-month intervention with follow-ups at 3 and 9 months

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of non-pharmacological treatments, including mindfulness, for adults with ADHD.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness has evidence as an effective intervention for core ADHD symptoms, though the evidence is weaker due to small participant numbers and methodological limitations.
population_specificity: Adults with ADHD

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) for people with recent-onset psychosis.
results_summary: The review found MBIs to be feasible and acceptable, with high recruitment and attendance rates, and promising positive effects on psychiatric and psychosocial outcomes. Participants reported high satisfaction with the interventions.
population_specificity: People with recent-onset psychosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of mindfulness training on burnout levels among nurses.
results_summary: Mindfulness training reduced burnout levels, with lower scores for emotional exhaustion and depersonalization and higher scores for personal accomplishment. The differences between intervention and control groups were statistically significant.
population_specificity: Nurses (632 participants across 17 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a Mindful Leadership course in reducing burnout symptoms, improving well-being, and enhancing leadership skills among medical specialists.
results_summary: The course significantly reduced depersonalization, worry, and negative work-home interference while improving mindfulness, life satisfaction, and self-reported ethical leadership, with small to large effect sizes. Facilitators included course appreciation, while time constraints were a major barrier.
population_specificity: Medical specialists

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a full online ACT intervention versus its isolated Open (acceptance, cognitive defusion) and Engaged (values, committed action) components on mental health outcomes in distressed college students.
results_summary: All three ACT conditions improved mental health symptoms compared to waitlist, with the Engaged and Full conditions showing greater rates of reliable change and improvements in positive mental health. The Full condition also demonstrated superior reductions in cognitive fusion compared to the isolated components.
population_specificity: Distressed college students (n=181)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current research on vaginal dilators, including patient behaviors and adjunctive treatments like mindfulness, to improve compliance and treatment success.
results_summary: Mindfulness was one of the activities women engaged in during dilation sessions. Factors like meditation and soothing music showed trends toward improved patient outcomes, though mindfulness itself was not independently analyzed for efficacy.
population_specificity: Women with genito-pelvic pain/penetration disorder (GPPPD), including postmenopausal women, cancer survivors, and those with pelvic floor disorders.
study_duration: 3-month follow-up data were recorded for some patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether mindfulness meditation could improve poststroke depression and quality of life in patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage in China.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in depression, trait mindfulness, social well-being, emotional well-being, and overall quality of life in the mindfulness intervention group. Physical well-being and NIH stroke scale scores improved in both the intervention and control groups over time.
population_specificity: Patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage in China.
effective_dosage: 2-month mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how men with a history of intimate partner violence (IPV) react emotionally and physiologically during angry rumination compared to distraction.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of mindfulness or the outcomes of the rumination and distraction manipulation.
population_specificity: Men with a history of intimate partner violence (IPV).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions, such as MBCT and ACT, in treating various anxiety disorders in adults.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based interventions, alongside CBT and digitalized approaches, can be effective in treating anxiety disorders, either as standalone or adjunctive therapies. Digital mindfulness interventions showed promise but require further evidence.
population_specificity: Adults with specific phobia, panic disorder, agoraphobia, social anxiety disorder, and generalized anxiety disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether interpersonal problems moderated depression outcomes between mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) and cognitive behavioral analysis system of psychotherapy (CBASP) in chronically depressed patients.
results_summary: Higher "vindictive/self-centered" scores were associated with better outcomes in MBCT than CBASP, while higher "nonassertive" scores were linked to better outcomes in CBASP than MBCT. The findings suggest MBCT may be preferable for vindictive/self-centered patients, whereas CBASP may be better for nonassertive patients.
population_specificity: Chronically depressed patients (n=68, split between MBCT and CBASP groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Mindful Mood Balance (MMB), a web-based mindfulness-based cognitive therapy, in treating residual depressive symptoms when added to usual depression care.
results_summary: MMB plus usual care significantly reduced residual depressive symptoms, increased remission rates, and decreased relapse rates compared to usual care alone. It also improved anxiety symptoms and mental functioning but showed no significant difference in physical functioning.
population_specificity: Adults with residual depressive symptoms recruited from primary care and behavioral health clinics.
effective_dosage: 8 online sessions over 3 months plus minimal phone or email coaching support.
study_duration: 3-month intervention with a 12-month follow-up (15 months total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence on prehabilitation in surgery, focusing on current strategies, knowledge gaps, and future research.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that prehabilitation programs, which include cognitive interventions to reduce stress and anxiety, have synergistic effects that improve postoperative outcomes, though more studies are needed to assess their impact across different patient groups.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing surgical interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the effects of psychosocial interventions, including mindfulness, on pain in advanced cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found a small but significant effect on pain intensity (d = -0.29) with highly heterogeneous effect sizes between studies. No intervention type was superior, but psychosocial interventions targeting pain distress may be more effective.
population_specificity: Advanced cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish dropout rates in RCTs of smartphone apps for depressive symptoms and compare retention rates between different types of apps, including mindfulness apps.
results_summary: The study found no difference in dropout rates between mindfulness and non-mindfulness app studies. Dropout rates were higher in larger studies but lower in studies offering human feedback and in-app mood monitoring.
population_specificity: Adults with depressive symptoms (clinically-diagnosed or self-reported).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of family-based mindfulness training (SFP-Mind) in preventing adolescent substance use and enhancing neurobehavioral self-regulation skills.
results_summary: The study compares a mindfulness-enhanced version of the Strengthening Families Program (SFP-Mind) with the standard SFP 10-14, focusing on adolescent alcohol use and secondary outcomes like mindfulness, impulsivity, and emotion regulation. Results are pending as the trial is ongoing, but the design suggests potential benefits for mental health and substance use prevention.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 10-14 years and their parents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based stress reduction in reducing caregiver-related strain and burden among caregivers of cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based stress reduction is likely to be effective in decreasing caregiver-related strain and burden, though stronger designs and larger samples are needed for conclusive evidence.
population_specificity: Caregivers of patients with cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Interventions (MBIs) in improving outcomes such as depression, anxiety, pain, and quality of life for individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The review found mixed results, with mindfulness showing effectiveness in reducing depressive symptoms (4 studies) and anxiety (3 studies), but limited impact on pain (only 1 study reported significant reductions) and no improvement in quality of life (2 studies). Study quality varied from high to low.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).

study_goal: To explore the effect of mindfulness interventions in improving outcomes for patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: Mindfulness interventions significantly improved pain intensity, depression, and symptoms (DSA28) in rheumatoid arthritis patients compared to conventional therapy, but showed no significant differences in anxiety and CPR.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (337 participants across 6 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the Four Immeasurables Meditations (FIM) intervention in reducing depressive symptoms through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found that FIM was effective in reducing depressive symptoms, with moderate effect sizes in randomized controlled trials (d = 0.38) and larger effects in uncontrolled trials (d = 0.87). Effects varied by protocol and were smaller in RCTs with active controls, but mindfulness and self-compassion were identified as key mechanisms of change.
population_specificity: Individuals with depressive symptoms (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether brief nurse-delivered behavioral interventions (mindfulness relaxation or relaxing music) could reduce anticipatory nausea and vomiting (ANV) in chemotherapy patients.
results_summary: Compared to standard care, mindfulness relaxation and relaxing music reduced anticipatory nausea at the midpoint of chemotherapy, but there was no difference at the end of chemotherapy or in anticipatory vomiting at either time point.
population_specificity: Mostly female (91.8%), white (86.1%) breast cancer patients (85%) with early-stage disease (Stage I-III).
study_duration: Administered at the midpoint and end of the chemotherapy course.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify effective resilience-promoting interventions, including mindfulness, in adults with cancer.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based interventions showed largely beneficial effects on resilience and post-traumatic growth in cancer patients, with effect sizes ranging from moderate to large. The benefits were more pronounced in interventions extending over more than 12 sessions.
population_specificity: Adults with cancer

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) on cancer-related fatigue (CRF) through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: MBSR significantly reduced cancer-related fatigue, particularly in lung cancer patients, and showed large effects when administered for 8 weeks under expert supervision compared to usual care or no intervention.
population_specificity: Cancer patients (3008 participants across 14 RCTs, with a focus on lung cancer patients).
effective_dosage: 8 weeks of MBSR (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether baseline mindfulness predicted lower PTSD severity and greater sustained abstinence in adults with PTSD and substance use disorders undergoing a 12-week cognitive-behavioral treatment program.
results_summary: Higher baseline mindfulness predicted lower end-of-treatment PTSD severity, particularly for intrusion, negative alterations in cognitions and mood, and arousal symptoms, but not avoidance symptoms or sustained abstinence.
population_specificity: 53 inner-city adults (51% women; 75.5% African American; mean age 45.42) with at least four DSM-5 PTSD symptoms and current DSM-IV substance dependence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Mindfulness Meditation (MM) against Hypnosis (HYP) and an Education Control (EDU) on pain intensity and secondary outcomes in Veterans with chronic pain.
results_summary: The study planned to assess MM's effectiveness on pain intensity, pain interference, sleep, depression, anxiety, and PTSD, with follow-ups at 3- and 6-months post-treatment, but results were not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Veterans with chronic pain due to a broad range of etiologies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and preliminary clinical efficacy of Mindfulness Training (MT) compared to Attention Bias Modification Training (ABMT) in individuals with overweight or obesity, focusing on acceptability, attendance rates, and potential mechanisms.
results_summary: The study provided preliminary evidence on the clinical efficacy of MT and ABMT for obesity, but specific results regarding Mindfulness's effects were not detailed in the abstract. Findings will inform the design of a larger RCT.
population_specificity: Adults with overweight or obesity (BMI ≥ 25 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether mindfulness training targeting distress tolerance could reduce smoking initiation risk in low-SES adolescents.
results_summary: The study found no significant evidence for differential efficacy of mindfulness training in smoking prevention or for its effects on distress tolerance. However, distress tolerance was negatively related to smoking propensity.
population_specificity: Low-income adolescents recruited from community afternoon programs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare changes in well-being over time for users of the Happify program, which incorporates mindfulness principles, between those with and without chronic conditions.
results_summary: Users with chronic conditions had lower baseline well-being but showed equivalent improvements to those without chronic conditions. Completing more activities over longer periods led to greater well-being improvements.
population_specificity: Happify users (821 total, 450 with chronic conditions such as arthritis, diabetes, insomnia, chronic pain, etc., and 371 without).
effective_dosage: Not specified (activities and games based on positive psychology, cognitive behavioral therapy, and mindfulness principles).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether KORSA workshops indirectly reduce anxiety, depression, and stress symptoms in university students by enhancing mindfulness and acceptance, as well as commitment and behavior change.
results_summary: The study found that KORSA workshops influenced anxiety, depression, and stress symptoms indirectly through improvements in mindfulness and acceptance, and commitment and behavior change processes.
population_specificity: University students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize and discuss the links between depression and diabetes, including the effectiveness of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy as a treatment for depression in individuals with diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based cognitive therapy is one of the effective treatments for depression in individuals with diabetes, alongside other interventions like antidepressant medication and cognitive-behavioral therapy. However, the abstract does not provide specific details on the magnitude of mindfulness's effects compared to other treatments.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 1 or type 2 diabetes who also have depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence and identify factors influencing the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) in reducing diabetes distress in adults with diabetes.
results_summary: MBIs significantly reduced diabetes distress, particularly in participants with elevated baseline distress, when using mindfulness-based stress reduction therapy, delivered in group format, or with home practice assignments. Long-term effects were more pronounced than short-term effects.
population_specificity: Adults with diabetes experiencing diabetes distress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of a combined mindfulness and metta meditation group treatment with individual CBT ("MeCBT") in reducing depressive symptoms in chronically depressed patients.
results_summary: The study expects a significant decline in depressive symptoms after the combined treatment compared to a wait-list control group, with secondary improvements in mindfulness, benevolence, and social functioning.
population_specificity: Chronically depressed patients
effective_dosage: Eight weekly group meditation sessions, one half-day retreat, and eight fortnightly individual CBT sessions

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how integrating drug-associated contexts, including mindfulness-based relapse prevention, could improve treatments for substance use disorders.
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness-based relapse prevention, alongside other approaches, could be beneficial in treating substance use disorders by addressing environmental and interoceptive drug stimuli. It highlights the translational relevance of such interventions in reducing drug-seeking behavior and cognitive expectancies.
population_specificity: Individuals with alcohol- and tobacco-related substance use disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether group MiCBT reduces depression and anxiety symptoms in patients with common mental health conditions and how it achieves these effects.
results_summary: The study is designed to compare MiCBT with a wait-list control, but results are not yet reported in the abstract. Primary outcomes will be measured using the DASS-21 and K10 scales.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-75, fluent in English, with a K10 score ≥20, recruited via medical practitioner referral.
effective_dosage: Not specified (8-week intervention with meditation practice recorded weekly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mind-body interventions, including mindfulness, in reducing psychological distress and improving marital function and pregnancy outcomes in infertile women/couples.
results_summary: Participation in mind-body interventions was associated with reduced anxiety and depression scores, though the reductions were of low to moderate amplitude. There was also a possible improvement in pregnancy rates.
population_specificity: Infertile women/couples undergoing fertility treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to propose and test a theoretical model for how mindfulness supports different forms of human motivation, grounded in self-determination theory.
results_summary: The study conducted a meta-analysis of 89 relevant studies to explore mindfulness's associations with motivation, suggesting it may foster healthy motivational states, though the abstract does not specify the exact outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether group body psychotherapy (BPT) and smartphone-triggered bodily interventions could improve bodily disturbances in post-treatment cancer patients.
results_summary: The study assessed improvements in bodily disturbances using the Body Image Scale (BIS) and secondary outcomes like mood, body mindfulness, and quality of life, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract. The design suggests potential efficacy, pending full results.
population_specificity: Post-treatment cancer patients (completed curative treatment ≥3 months prior) suffering from bodily disturbances.
effective_dosage: Smartphone-triggered bodily interventions were provided 6 days weekly for 5 consecutive weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) and Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) versus usual care in reducing chronic pain intensity and related symptoms in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study hypothesized that MBCT and CBT would lead to significantly greater reductions in average pain intensity compared to usual care at post-treatment and 6-month follow-up, with mindfulness, pain catastrophizing, and behavioral activation potentially moderating treatment response.
population_specificity: Adults with MS and chronic pain.
effective_dosage: Eight group sessions delivered via videoconferencing.
study_duration: Eight sessions (mid-treatment, post-treatment, and 6-month follow-up assessments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness training (MFT) improves extinction retention of threat-related responses, potentially clarifying its role in treating anxiety and trauma-related disorders.
results_summary: The MFT group showed reduced spontaneous recovery of threat-related arousal responses on day 2 compared to the waitlist group, but MFT had no effect on acquisition or extinction of conditioned responses on day 1. This suggests MFT may enhance emotional functioning by improving extinction retention.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects (n=29, with 14 in the MFT group and 15 in the waitlist group).
effective_dosage: 4-week MFT intervention delivered via a smartphone app (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of cognitive restructuring (CR) and detached mindfulness (DM) in treating obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) using ecological momentary assessment (EMA).
results_summary: Both CR and DM showed a general pre-post increase in strategy application, but no significant differences were found between the two treatments in frequency, difficulty, or relief. The interventions equally promoted treatment effects without specificity.
population_specificity: 39 OCD patients in a randomized clinical trial.
effective_dosage: Not specified (smartphone-based EMA with 10 random prompts per day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness practice could improve functional brain connectivity and cognitive function in older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: Participants in the mindfulness group showed significantly better temporal global efficiency in brain networks, localized improvements in specific brain regions, and enhanced verbal recognition memory compared to controls.
population_specificity: Older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a mindful self-compassion intervention on preventing postpartum depression in symptomatic pregnant women.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvement in depressive and anxiety behaviors, increased mindfulness and self-compassion, and substantial improvement in mother and infant well-being compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Symptomatic pregnant women at risk of postpartum depression.
effective_dosage: 6-week Internet-based Mindful Self-Compassion Program (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a tailored psychological intervention, including mindfulness, in reducing psychological distress and improving mental adjustment and quality of life among cancer patients with adjustment disorders.
results_summary: The study assessed the effectiveness of a psychological intervention with mindfulness components, but specific results regarding mindfulness alone were not detailed in the abstract. The primary outcome was psychological distress (HADS), with secondary outcomes including mental adjustment to cancer (MAC) and health-related quality of life (EORTC QLQ-C30).
population_specificity: Cancer patients diagnosed with adjustment disorders after cancer treatment.
effective_dosage: Not specified (mindfulness was part of a broader intervention with up to 6 sessions per module).
study_duration: Measures were taken at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months after randomization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand older adults' perceptions of initiating and maintaining mindfulness and exercise practices, including benefits, barriers, and facilitators.
results_summary: Mindfulness training increased awareness, self-reflection, and self-acceptance, improved self-care habits, and enhanced familial and social relationships. Time management was a key barrier, while social benefits and community were primary motivators.
population_specificity: Adults aged 65-85 who recently initiated Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction (MBSR), structured exercise, or both.

study_goal: To review the current use, evidence-base, and effectiveness of mindfulness- and compassion-based interventions for family carers of older adults to aid healthcare practitioners in referral decisions.
results_summary: The study identified seven types of mindfulness- or compassion-based interventions used with family carers, showing potential utility in supporting carers, but the evidence was insufficient and heterogeneous to confirm effectiveness. Attrition rates (18%) suggested acceptable feasibility.
population_specificity: Family carers of older adults, including sub-groups caring for individuals with dementia, cancer, ALS, chronic conditions, cirrhosis, and Parkinson’s disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions, including mindfulness, in improving health, wellbeing, and job-related outcomes for nurses.
results_summary: Mindfulness interventions showed mixed results, with stress being one of the more successfully improved outcomes (49/66 studies reported improvements). However, work-related outcomes had the lowest success rate (16/32).
population_specificity: Nurses (total sample of 16,129 participants across 136 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare mindfulness, distraction, and associative focus strategies to improve affective response to exercise and promote exercise behavior in insufficiently active individuals.
results_summary: Mindfulness and distraction maintained more positive affective responses to exercise over time compared to associative focus. Mindfulness participants exercised more days during follow-up, while distraction reduced perceived exertion.
population_specificity: 78 insufficiently active individuals (mean age 26.82, 74% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of mindfulness meditation as a non-pharmacological intervention for pediatric functional abdominal pain disorders (FAPDs).
results_summary: The abstract mentions that mindfulness meditation is being investigated for pediatric functional pain, suggesting it as a promising psychological advance, but specific results or outcomes are not detailed.
population_specificity: Children with functional abdominal pain disorders (FAPDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single 20-minute session of mindful breathing could reduce perceived suffering and alter bispectral index scores (BIS) among informal palliative care caregivers.
results_summary: The study found that the mindful breathing group showed a significantly greater reduction in suffering scores compared to the supportive listening control group at the 20-minute mark. Changes in BIS were also measured, though specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adult informal caregivers of palliative care patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether three distinct mindfulness-based training modules (Presence, Affect, Perspective) differentially reduce inflammatory biomarkers (IL-6, hs-CRP) in healthy adults.
results_summary: No group-level effect of training was observed, but trend-level interactions suggested that the Presence module reduced IL-6 in participants with higher baseline inflammation and hs-CRP in males. Mindfulness-based interventions may be less effective in healthy, low-stressed adults compared to vulnerable populations.
population_specificity: 298 healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if telephone-delivered mindfulness training (MT) was feasible and acceptable for improving medication adherence and reducing sexual risk behavior in people living with HIV.
results_summary: Both MT and health coaching (HC) groups showed improvements in medication adherence, mindfulness, sexual risk reduction, and reductions in anxiety, depressive symptoms, stress, and impulsivity, but no significant differences were found between the groups. Most participants reported satisfaction with their assigned intervention.
population_specificity: People living with HIV (N=42; 50% female; mean age=47.5 years).
study_duration: Pre- and post-intervention, with a 3-month follow-up (exact duration of intervention not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Integrative Medical Group Visits (IMGV), which include mindfulness techniques, compared to standard primary care visits for reducing chronic pain and depressive symptoms.
results_summary: The study found no differences in pain or depression levels between the IMGV and control groups at any time point. However, the IMGV group had fewer emergency department visits at 9 weeks and reduced pain medication use at 21 weeks compared to controls.
population_specificity: Predominantly low-income, racially diverse adults with nonspecific chronic pain and depressive symptoms.
effective_dosage: 9 weekly 2.5-hour in-person IMGV sessions, followed by 12 weeks of online platform access and a final IMGV session at 21 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the methodological quality and effectiveness of interventions, including mindfulness, for managing occupational stress among intensive and critical care nurses.
results_summary: The review found that mindfulness-based interventions were more effective than control conditions in reducing occupational stress among intensive and critical care nurses, though it highlighted the need for higher-quality studies.
population_specificity: Intensive and critical care unit nurses

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness, among other communicative and educative strategies, on behavior modification and exercise compliance in patients with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: Mindfulness was included as one of several interventions, but the abstract does not specify its individual efficacy. The study found that multimodal interventions, pain science education, and graded exposure were most effective for behavior modification and long-term compliance, while mindfulness was not singled out for detailed results.
population_specificity: Adults (≥ 18 years) with chronic low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of psychological interventions, including mindfulness, in reducing cancer-related fatigue in post-treatment survivors.
results_summary: The review found tentative support for psychological interventions, including mindfulness, in reducing fatigue among cancer survivors, with 23 out of 33 studies reporting significant effects. However, heterogeneity in study designs and limited high-quality evidence precluded definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Adult cancer patients who had completed treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update a previous systematic review and conduct a meta-analysis on the efficacy of Mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) for improving physical symptoms, particularly fatigue, in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: The study found that MBIs were effective for reducing fatigue in PwMS, with a standardized mean difference of 0.24. However, the optimal MBI approach remains unclear, and further research is needed on optimization and comparative effectiveness.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS)
effective_dosage: Treatment duration was 6-9 weeks; specific dosage not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions on anxiety, depression, quality of life, fatigue, stress, posttraumatic growth, and mindfulness among adult cancer patients and survivors.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based interventions significantly reduced anxiety, depression, fatigue, and stress while improving quality of life, posttraumatic growth, and mindfulness. MBAT showed the strongest effects, followed by MBSR and MBCR, across different cancer types.
population_specificity: Adult cancer patients and survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare social cognition (SC) abilities and mindfulness measures between patients with schizophrenia (SZ), obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), and healthy controls (HCs), and explore potential associations between mindfulness and SC.
results_summary: The study found that both SZ and OCD groups showed impaired SC abilities compared to HCs, with no significant difference between the clinical groups. Mindfulness measures correlated with SC, suggesting potential benefits for transdiagnostic interventions.
population_specificity: 30 SZ outpatients, 31 OCD outpatients, and 30 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and summarize studies on mindfulness approaches for modifying eating behaviors and treating eating disorders in adolescents.
results_summary: The review identified a small number of studies suggesting mindfulness may improve eating disorder-related psychopathology in adolescents, though remission rates for existing treatments remain low (30-40%).
population_specificity: Adolescents with eating disorders or disordered eating behaviors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of video-based mindfulness-based cognitive therapy with traditional cognitive behavioral treatment for improving orgasm achievement in women with sexual dysfunction.
results_summary: Both mindfulness-based cognitive therapy and traditional CBT improved sexual functioning, reduced sexual distress, and enhanced desire, arousal, orgasm, and satisfaction. However, only CBT showed significant reductions in sexual pain.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-58 with difficulties achieving orgasm (N=65).
study_duration: Treatment duration not explicitly stated; follow-up was 2 months post-completion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a brief mindfulness training program on emotional regulation, cognitive rumination, psychological well-being, and depressive symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that a four-session mindfulness program significantly increased psychological well-being, reduced depressive symptoms, decreased emotional suppression and rumination, and improved cognitive reappraisal.
population_specificity: 103 voluntary participants (51 in the experimental group, 52 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness-based relapse prevention (MBRP) combined with tDCS could reduce alcohol cue-related hypersensitivity and craving in individuals with AUD.
results_summary: The study found that both craving ratings and the late positive potential (LPP) significantly decreased in response to alcohol cues post-treatment, with craving reductions linked to the number of MBRP sessions attended. Active tDCS did not affect craving but was associated with greater LPP amplitudes across image types.
population_specificity: Individuals with alcohol use disorder (AUD) (n=68, with n=37 completing follow-up).
effective_dosage: Up to eight sessions of MBRP coupled with active or sham tDCS.
study_duration: Up to eight sessions (duration not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of mindfulness and yoga interventions in improving sleep quality and insomnia during pregnancy.
results_summary: Preliminary support was found for mindfulness and yoga interventions in ameliorating poor sleep quality and insomnia during pregnancy, though the evidence remains limited due to the small number of studies and lack of high-quality randomized controlled trials.
population_specificity: Pregnant women of any age and gestational age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether psychosomatic therapy, including mindfulness, is cost-effective in reducing symptoms and improving functioning in patients with medically unexplained symptoms (MUS) who frequently consult their GP.
results_summary: The study expects psychosomatic therapy, which includes mindfulness, to improve symptoms, daily functioning, and disability while reducing consultation frequency and referrals to secondary care, suggesting it provides value for money for MUS patients.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18 years and older who frequently consult their GP with medically unexplained symptoms (MUS).
effective_dosage: 6 to 12 sessions of 30-45 minutes each, delivered by a specialized exercise or physical therapist.
study_duration: Assessments at baseline, 4 months, and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) as a secondary prevention strategy to improve psychosocial well-being and cardiovascular outcomes in cardiac patients during their first year of recovery.
results_summary: MBSR showed significant improvements in depression and anxiety at 3 months, with a trend toward better health-related quality of life. Cardiovascular risk factors also improved, though effects attenuated by 9 months, except in participants with baseline depression, where benefits persisted.
population_specificity: Cardiac patients eligible for cardiac rehabilitation (mean age 58.6 years; 38% female; 77% white).
effective_dosage: 8-week MBSR group intervention (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the impact of RAP Club, a trauma-informed intervention for eighth graders that includes mindfulness as a core component, on emotional, behavioral, and academic outcomes.
results_summary: The study assessed student outcomes using self-report surveys and teacher ratings at baseline, post-intervention, and 4-month follow-up, but specific results regarding mindfulness's effects are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Eighth-grade students in 32 urban public schools (n = 800) exposed to chronic stress and trauma.
study_duration: Duration of intervention not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness-based programs could effectively reduce stress and anxiety in adolescents exposed to interparental conflict, and whether tailored, real-time delivery of mindfulness components could enhance treatment efficacy.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of mindfulness, as it appears to describe a proposed study rather than reporting outcomes.
population_specificity: Adolescents exposed to interparental conflict.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) in secondary-care settings for patients with anxiety disorders who had not remitted after pharmacotherapy.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in both State and Trait Anxiety subscales of the STAI for the MBCT group compared to the control group, indicating MBCT's effectiveness in treating anxiety disorders in treatment-resistant patients.
population_specificity: Adults aged 20-75 with panic disorder/agoraphobia or social anxiety disorder (DSM-IV criteria) who had not remitted after pharmacotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify instructional design components of internet-based mindfulness interventions and assess their association with intervention effectiveness.
results_summary: More effective interventions included higher levels of supportive information, part-task practice, and just-in-time information, with effectiveness increasing with the level of support. The average duration of interventions varied, but effectiveness was not consistently linked to duration.
population_specificity: Not specified (general applicability to internet-based mindfulness interventions).
effective_dosage: Not specified (instructional design components assessed, not dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acceptability, feasibility, and effects of a customized Mindfulness-Based Blood Pressure Reduction (MB-BP) program on self-regulation mechanisms and blood pressure determinants.
results_summary: The MB-BP program showed high acceptability and feasibility, with significant improvements in self-regulation outcomes (attention control, emotion regulation, self-awareness) and modifiable hypertension determinants (physical activity, diet, alcohol consumption). It also demonstrated a mean 6.1 mmHg reduction in systolic blood pressure, with more pronounced effects in uncontrolled hypertensives (15.1 mmHg reduction).
population_specificity: Adults with hypertension or at risk for hypertension (53 eligible participants, 48 enrolled).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and initial efficacy of an integrated psychosocial treatment combining Acceptance and Commitment Therapy and Mindfulness-Based Relapse Prevention for Veterans with chronic pain and hazardous opioid use.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in opioid misuse, pain interference, and pain behavior for the integrated intervention group compared to usual care, supporting its feasibility and efficacy. Recruitment fell short of targets, but retention and treatment completion rates were high.
population_specificity: Military Veterans with chronic pain and evidence of hazardous opioid use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of an adapted Mindfulness-Based Childbirth and Parenting (MBCP) program, including compassion training, in reducing perinatal depression among pregnant women in Spanish primary care settings.
results_summary: The study proposes to evaluate the program's impact on depression (measured by EPDS) and secondary outcomes like stress, mindfulness, and self-compassion, but results are not yet reported as it is a planned RCT.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (n=122) and their partners in Spanish primary care settings.
study_duration: Assessments at baseline, post-treatment, and at three and six months after childbirth (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the mindfulness-based program CARE could sustain long-term reductions in psychological distress and improvements in emotion regulation and mindfulness among teachers in high-poverty elementary schools.
results_summary: CARE teachers showed sustained significant decreases in psychological distress and physical distress, along with continued improvements in emotion regulation and some mindfulness dimensions at a 9.5-month follow-up compared to controls.
population_specificity: 224 elementary school teachers in high-poverty areas of New York City.
study_duration: Intervention duration not specified; follow-up assessment at 9.5 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of a brief mindfulness intervention in reducing anxiety in early psychosis patients and whether symptom burden affects the therapeutic response.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant reduction in anxiety scores (from 4.6 to 1.7) after a 3-minute mindfulness exercise, with no influence from symptom burden.
population_specificity: Early psychosis patients with less than 30 months of antipsychotic exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy for sexuality (MBCT-S) on sexual function and intimacy among older adult women with epilepsy in Iran.
results_summary: The study found improvements in sexual function, sexual distress, and intimacy in both intervention groups (PP and PPHP) at one-month and six-month follow-ups, with the PPHP group showing greater improvement in intimacy and sexual function at six months.
population_specificity: Older adult women with epilepsy (WWE) in Iran, along with their partners and healthcare providers.
effective_dosage: Eight weeks of MBCT-S sessions for patients and partners; three additional individual sessions on sexual counseling for healthcare providers in the PPHP group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of mindfulness-based yogic breathing (MB) versus cognitive strategy (CS) and no-treatment (NT) controls on craving, affect, withdrawal, and smoking behavior in smokers.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study examined the comparative efficacy of MB, CS, and NT on smoking-related outcomes.
population_specificity: Smokers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a mindfulness eating (ME) program in reducing emotional eating among Spanish adults with overweight/obesity in primary care settings.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a planned evaluation of ME's impact on emotional eating, binge eating, anxiety, depression, and other outcomes, but results are not yet reported as it is a study protocol.
population_specificity: Spanish adults with overweight/obesity from primary care health centers in Zaragoza, Spain.
effective_dosage: Seven sessions delivered by a clinical psychologist (frequency not specified).
study_duration: Not specified (follow-up measures planned at 1 year).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) on university students' mental and physical health through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: MBIs showed small to moderate improvements in distress, anxiety, depression, well-being, rumination, and mindfulness shortly after intervention, but no benefits for physical health measures like blood pressure or sleep. Effects on distress and mindfulness lasted beyond three months, though higher-quality research is needed due to generally high risk of bias in included studies.
population_specificity: University students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness meditation-based body scan exercises, combined with vibrator-assisted start-stop exercises, could enhance the treatment effect for premature ejaculation (PE).
results_summary: The interventions reduced PE symptoms with large effect sizes, suggesting mindfulness combined with physical exercises was effective. Follow-up data at 3 and 6 months indicated sustained benefits.
population_specificity: 50 participants with PE, mean age 41.7 years.
effective_dosage: Mindfulness meditation-based body scan exercises performed 3 times a week.
study_duration: 6 weeks, with follow-ups at 3 and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether school-based mindfulness interventions could effectively reduce internalising difficulties (anxiety and depression) in children and young people in England.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a large-scale trial to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness and relaxation interventions, but specific results regarding efficacy are not yet provided in the abstract. The trial aims to assess feasibility, effectiveness, and cost-effectiveness of these interventions.
population_specificity: Primary and secondary school pupils in England (17,600 participants across 160 primary and 64 secondary schools).
study_duration: Measures collected at baseline, 3-6 months, and 9-12 months after intervention commencement.
