study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) improves empathy in individuals with social anxiety disorder (SAD) compared to cognitive-behavioral group therapy (CBGT) and a wait-list condition.
results_summary: MBSR did not show significant improvements in empathy compared to CBGT, which improved positive affective empathy. No differential changes in other empathy indices were observed across the three conditions.
population_specificity: Individuals with social anxiety disorder (SAD)
study_duration: Not specified (assessed at baseline, posttreatment/wait-list, and 1-year follow-up)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the comparative effectiveness of educational setting-based interventions, including mindfulness, in preventing anxiety and depression in children and young people.
results_summary: Mindfulness and relaxation-based interventions showed a reduction in anxiety symptoms in universal secondary settings (SMD -0.65, 95% credible interval -1.14 to -0.19), but there was little evidence supporting their effectiveness in preventing depression.
population_specificity: Children and young people aged 4-18 years in educational settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of a Mindfulness-Based Childbirth and Parenting Program (MBCP) in reducing perceived stress and preventing perinatal depression compared to an active control condition (Lamaze childbirth class).
results_summary: MBCP significantly reduced perceived stress and depressive symptoms while increasing positive states of mind and self-reported mindfulness compared to the control. Changes in mindfulness, particularly non-reactivity and non-judging, appeared to mediate these effects.
population_specificity: First-time pregnant women (n = 197) at risk of perinatal depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the impact of behavioral SUD interventions, particularly mindfulness-based and affect-regulation treatments, on emotional outcomes in individuals with substance use disorder.
results_summary: The study found a small but significant effect of SUD interventions on reducing negative emotion, with mindfulness-based and affect-regulation treatments showing notable efficacy. Results for positive emotion were preliminary due to limited sample sizes.
population_specificity: Individuals with substance use disorder (SUD) enrolled in clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review emerging evidence on novel treatments for anxiety disorders, including mindfulness, to assess their effectiveness.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness was among the interventions recommended for anxiety, though therapist-oriented approaches showed greater results compared to computer-delivered interventions.
population_specificity: Adults with anxiety disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of cognitive-behavioral programs and meditation strategies on stress, anxiety, and depression in students and identify determinants of treatment success.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found average effect sizes of -0.41 for stress, -0.37 for anxiety, and -0.30 for depression, indicating moderate reductions in these symptoms. Significant correlations were found for the type of treatment relating to stress.
population_specificity: Students facing high academic demands and learning difficulties.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the effectiveness of a proprioceptive training program as a complementary therapy to a traditional protocol of education, mindfulness, and exercise training for managing fibromyalgia associated with imbalance.
results_summary: The study found that training supplemented with proprioception exercises improved balance in fibromyalgia patients, with significant differences in balance tests compared to baseline. Both groups showed reduced pain and improved functional performance, but no significant differences were observed between them in pain rating and quality of life measures. The positive effects did not persist long-term after the program ended.
population_specificity: 84 women with primary fibromyalgia associated with imbalance.
effective_dosage: Each session lasted 40-60 minutes, performed three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effectiveness of cognitive rehabilitation (excluding mindfulness) for attention deficits in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found no convincing evidence for the effectiveness of cognitive rehabilitation on attentional functions, functional abilities, mood, or quality of life in stroke survivors, though there may be a short-term improvement in divided attention.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with demonstrable or self-reported attentional deficits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between psychological flexibility (including mindfulness) and continued substance use in adults with opioid use disorder (OUD) and chronic pain.
results_summary: Greater mindfulness significantly predicted a higher probability of abstaining from illicit substance use (OR = 1.59, p < 0.05). No other psychological flexibility variables were associated with continued substance use.
population_specificity: Predominantly Hispanic adults (84%) with OUD and co-occurring chronic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether brief breath counting training, a component of mindfulness, could reduce drinkers' sensitivity to stress-induced negative mood and alcohol-seeking behavior.
results_summary: The breath counting intervention improved subjective mood, attenuated stress-induced mood worsening, and accelerated recovery from stress-induced increases in alcohol-seeking behavior, though the effect was weaker in more alcohol-dependent participants.
population_specificity: 192 student drinkers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a child-focused mindfulness intervention in increasing vegetable intake among children aged five years and under.
results_summary: One trial examined mindfulness and reported a positive intervention effect on child vegetable intake, but the evidence quality was low, and the effect size was not quantified in the abstract.
population_specificity: Children aged five years and under.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefit of a brief, universal resilience program incorporating mindfulness for improving mental health outcomes in first-year college students.
results_summary: The resilience program, which included mindfulness, showed no immediate improvement in depression but demonstrated significant reductions at semester-end. It also improved perceived stress, emotion regulation, mindfulness, and CBT skills, with CBT skills mediating clinical improvements.
population_specificity: First-year students at a private, midwestern university.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to collate case reports of psychotic disorders associated with meditative practice and discuss the relationship between psychosis and meditation.
results_summary: The review identified 28 cases of psychotic disorders linked to meditation, with varied diagnoses and precipitating factors, but could not establish a causal relationship. The study also acknowledges existing research on meditation's beneficial effects for psychotic disorders.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 18-57 years with reported psychotic disorders (acute psychosis, schizophrenia, mania with psychotic symptoms, schizoaffective disorder).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the UPRIGHT intervention, which includes Mindfulness, in promoting mental well-being and resilience among adolescents.
results_summary: The study expects short- to medium-term improvements in mental well-being by enhancing resilience capacities, including Mindfulness, but final results are pending as the intervention is ongoing.
population_specificity: Adolescents (around 6000 participants) and their families across five Pan-European regions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical effects of a 12-session mindfulness-based therapy (MBT) on reducing psychogenic nonepileptic seizure (PNES) frequency, intensity, and duration, as well as improving quality of life and psychiatric symptom severity.
results_summary: The study found that MBT significantly reduced PNES frequency and intensity while improving quality of life, with 70% of participants reporting at least a 50% reduction in seizure frequency and 50% achieving remission by the end of treatment. However, reductions in event duration and psychiatric symptom severity were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 49 patients with documented PNES (confirmed by video EEG) at Brigham and Women's Hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of cognitive remediation group therapy (CRGT), which combines mindfulness-based stress reduction with brain training activities, compared to mutual aid group therapy in individuals with mild HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND).
results_summary: The study primarily assessed feasibility and acceptability, with secondary exploratory outcomes including stress, anxiety, coping, and use of intervention activities. Results on efficacy were not yet available as the abstract describes a pilot trial protocol.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥40 years with mild HAND, known HIV status for 5+ years, English fluency, and ability to consent and attend group therapy.
effective_dosage: Eight weekly 3-hour sessions of CRGT (mindfulness-based stress reduction combined with brain training activities).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of the ENHANCE program, which includes mindfulness, in increasing subjective well-being (SWB) and to examine the mechanistic processes behind these changes.
results_summary: The study found that ENHANCE effectively increased SWB, whether delivered in-person or online, with improvements linked to the development of targeted skills like mindfulness. Gains in SWB were maintained over 6 months in the treatment group and replicated in the waitlist group.
population_specificity: 155 participants (55 in-person, 100 online) in a randomized controlled trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and engagement of a cognitive-behavioral, mindfulness, and values-based intervention for managing distress, pain, and fatigue in advanced breast cancer patients across the US and Singapore.
results_summary: The intervention was feasible, acceptable, and engaging, with stable or improved anxiety, depression, and fatigue scores in intervention participants compared to worsening symptoms in controls. Effect sizes were generally larger in the US sample than in Singapore.
population_specificity: Women with advanced breast cancer (N = 85) in the US and Singapore.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cost-utility and quality of life improvements of group-based face-to-face MBCT and individual internet-based eMBCT versus treatment as usual (TAU) in distressed cancer patients.
results_summary: Both MBCT and eMBCT reduced societal costs and work-related productivity losses while improving quality of life compared to TAU, with sustained benefits at 9-month follow-up. The interventions were cost-saving and demonstrated clinically meaningful improvements in utility scores.
population_specificity: Heterogeneous cancer patients with psychological distress (n=245).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the synergistic effects of psilocybin and mindfulness meditation, including predictors of acute response and long-term psychosocial outcomes.
results_summary: Psilocybin increased meditation depth and positive self-dissolution experiences without anxiety, enhanced post-intervention mindfulness, and improved psychosocial functioning at 4-month follow-up. Meditation appeared to amplify psilocybin's benefits while mitigating dysphoric responses.
population_specificity: 39 meditators during a 5-day mindfulness group retreat.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether improvements in mindfulness and distress tolerance mediate the relationship between DBT skills training and clinical outcomes in patients with BPD.
results_summary: The study found that improvements in mindfulness and distress tolerance independently mediated the relationship between DBT-S and posttreatment general psychopathology, suggesting these skills are key mechanisms of DBT's effectiveness.
population_specificity: 84 patients diagnosed with borderline personality disorder (BPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of mindfulness-based interventions on psychological and physical outcomes and health-related quality of life in patients with heart failure.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based interventions significantly reduced depression (three studies) and anxiety (two studies) and improved health-related quality of life (two studies), but effects on physical symptoms were inconsistent, and physical function showed no significant changes (one study).
population_specificity: Adults with heart failure (467 patients across five studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore associations between non-adherence to early coronary artery bypass graft rehabilitation and sociodemographic/clinical baseline data, including the use of a mindfulness programme.
results_summary: The study found low adherence to physical rehabilitation post-discharge, and the mindfulness programme was not utilized by participants. Psycho-educational consultations were widely accepted, but mindfulness participation was not addressed in detail.
population_specificity: Coronary artery bypass graft patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether early therapeutic alliance predicts treatment dropout in MBCT or eMBCT, compare the development of therapeutic alliance in both conditions, and examine its relationship with psychological distress reduction and mental well-being improvement.
results_summary: The study found that therapeutic alliance develops similarly in eMBCT and MBCT, early alliance did not predict dropout, and stronger alliance predicted reduced psychological distress and increased mental well-being in both conditions, with a stronger relationship in group-based MBCT.
population_specificity: Distressed cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of a mindfulness-based mental health prevention program compared to usual care in a multi-site field setting in Germany.
results_summary: The mindfulness program was cost-effective from a societal perspective, providing significant improvements in mental health (1.97 units on the HADS) at lower costs (€-57). From a healthcare perspective, it achieved incremental benefits at additional costs (€181), with an ICER of €91 per unit improvement.
population_specificity: Participants (N=1166) recruited via a large statutory health insurance fund in Germany.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) in addressing physician burnout and improving mental health.
results_summary: The study found that MBSR and CBT modalities were more effective than other therapies in reducing burnout, with group interventions outperforming individual therapy. Systemic/organizational interventions showed greater efficacy than individual-level approaches.
population_specificity: Physicians and healthcare professionals experiencing burnout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize attentional bias studies using event-related potentials (ERPs) to develop a neural chronometry model of attentional bias in healthy and anxious populations.
results_summary: The study found that both healthy and anxious populations show early ERP modulations (P1, N170, P2, N2pc) in response to threat, but healthy populations more clearly modulate later components (P3), indicating differences in conscious threat processing and disengagement.
population_specificity: Healthy and anxious populations (generalized from 28 attentional bias studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a mindfulness-based childbirth and parenting program in improving psychological health during the postpartum period.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced postpartum self-perceived stress and depression compared to the comparison group, though no significant difference in mindfulness scores was observed. The program provided long-term benefits for women transitioning into parenthood.
population_specificity: 74 pregnant women between 13 and 28-weeks gestation.
effective_dosage: Eight weekly 3-hour classes and one 7-hour silent meditation session.
study_duration: 8 weeks (weekly classes) plus one full-day session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of therapist-assisted internet-delivered mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (iMBCT) for reducing anxiety and depression in cancer survivors.
results_summary: iMBCT showed significant effects for reducing anxiety (Cohen's d = 0.45) and depressive symptoms (d = 0.42) post-intervention, with anxiety benefits maintained at 6-month follow-up, but not depressive symptoms.
population_specificity: Breast (n = 137) and prostate cancer (n = 13) survivors with anxiety and depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cognitively-Based Compassion Training (CBCT) could reduce physiological stress in infants and young children by intervening with their parents.
results_summary: Children of parents in the CBCT group showed significant decreases in cortisol levels post-intervention compared to controls, but parental cortisol and self-reported measures (stress, self-compassion, mindfulness) did not significantly change except for a small effect on clinical parenting stress.
population_specificity: Parents of infants and young children (ages 4 months to 5 years).
effective_dosage: 20 hours of CBCT administered over 8–10 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review published studies on the efficacy of mindfulness-based therapies (MBT) in treating sexual dysfunctions.
results_summary: MBT improved subjectively evaluated arousal, desire, sexual satisfaction, and reduced fear linked with sexual activity in women, but did not significantly reduce pain during sexual activities. One study found evidence for MBT's efficacy in treating male erectile dysfunction.
population_specificity: Men and women with sexual dysfunctions, including genital-pelvic pain, desire/arousal disorders, and erectile dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of self-selected and researcher-selected music on reducing induced negative affect (anxiety and physiological arousal) and increasing state mindfulness.
results_summary: Music listening (both self-selected and researcher-selected) significantly reduced anxiety compared to a silent control in Study 1, but not compared to an active control in Study 2. However, music listening increased state mindfulness, which predicted lower anxiety after self-selected music.
population_specificity: Undergraduates (70 in Study 1, 75 in Study 2)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of an online mindfulness-based intervention and determine its effect on pharmacy students' wellbeing.
results_summary: The intervention group showed increased professional efficacy and observing scores, with males improving in stress and non-judgement levels and females in professional efficacy. Participants reported stress reduction and heightened emotional awareness.
population_specificity: Pharmacy students at four schools in Ireland

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy for migraine (MBCT-M) in reducing migraine-related disability.
results_summary: MBCT-M significantly reduced headache-related disability (HDI scores decreased by -14.3 vs. -0.2 in the control group) and attack-level migraine-related disability (MIDI scores decreased by -0.6 vs. +0.3 in the control group), though no significant changes were observed in headache frequency or pain intensity.
population_specificity: Adults with migraine (6-30 headache days/month), predominantly White, Non-Hispanic women with graduate degrees.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of two 8-week group modules (SMBCT and COMET) + treatment as usual (TAU) for patients with personality disorders, focusing on predictors and mediators of change.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effectiveness of the interventions, but the study design suggests an investigation into their efficacy for targeted patient problems.
population_specificity: Patients with personality disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) improves general health and reduces stress in Chinese military recruits with psychological distress.
results_summary: The MBSR group showed greater improvements in mindfulness, general health, and stress reduction compared to the waitlist group at the 12-week follow-up. The study suggests MBSR may be a promising intervention for this population.
population_specificity: Chinese military recruits with psychological distress

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Oriented Recovery Enhancement (MORE) could improve positive psychological health and reduce pain severity and opioid misuse risk in chronic pain patients receiving long-term opioid therapy.
results_summary: MORE significantly increased positive psychological health, reduced pain severity by posttreatment, and decreased opioid misuse risk by 3-month follow-up compared to the support group. Positive psychological health mediated the effect of MORE on pain reduction, which subsequently predicted lower opioid misuse risk.
population_specificity: Patients with opioid-treated chronic pain (N = 95; mean age 56.8 ± 11.7; 66% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors associated with mindful eating among clinical nurses.
results_summary: The study found that mindful eating scores were positively associated with mental well-being but lower among obese participants and those with higher occupational stress.
population_specificity: 205 clinical nurses

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine which components of online acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) are most effective for improving mental health and psychosocial functioning.
results_summary: All ACT conditions (ACT-Open, ACT-Engaged, ACT-Combined) significantly improved mental health and psychological flexibility, though ACT-Combined showed superior psychosocial functioning compared to ACT-Open at post-treatment and ACT-Engaged worsened at follow-up. The online platform was well-received with high satisfaction.
population_specificity: 55 adults with psychological problems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine recent evidence on adjunctive treatments, including mindfulness, for adolescent substance use disorders.
results_summary: The study suggests mindfulness may have clinical utility as an adjunctive treatment for adolescent substance use disorders, alongside well-established psychosocial interventions.
population_specificity: Adolescents with substance use disorders

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a 9-week Mindfulness-Based Intervention (MBI) on resilience, socio-emotional functioning, and depressive symptoms in school children and adolescents compared to relaxation programs and teaching as usual.
results_summary: Mindfulness showed slight benefits over relaxation and teaching as usual, improving resilience at 9 weeks and reducing depressive symptoms in girls at 26 weeks. It also enhanced socio-emotional functioning in 7th graders at both 9 and 26 weeks compared to relaxation.
population_specificity: Finnish school children and adolescents aged 12-15 years (6th to 8th graders) from 56 schools.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) in improving pain and physical function in patients undergoing total joint arthroplasty (TJA) with psychological distress.
results_summary: The MBSR group showed significantly greater improvements in knee pain, function, and global scores at 12 months post-surgery compared to the treatment-as-usual group, though no differences were observed in secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with arthritis scheduled for TJA and a well-being score <40 (Short Form-12 Survey).
effective_dosage: Eight-week MBSR program (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-intensity mindfulness interventions (face-to-face group and Internet-delivered) versus treatment as usual (TAU) for treating depression in primary care settings.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) showed significant improvements in depressive symptoms, with outcomes measured at multiple follow-ups. The abstract suggests potential benefits of MBIs as alternatives to pharmacotherapy, though specific efficacy data are not detailed.
population_specificity: Approximately 120 depressed patients in primary care settings.
effective_dosage: Four modules (specific dosage or frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated; follow-ups at post-treatment, 6 months, and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based stress reduction and caregiver training interventions in reducing anxiety, depression, and caregiver burden among ALS caregivers.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized controlled trial design to assess primary outcomes (anxiety and depression symptoms) and secondary outcomes (caregiver burden and quality of life), but results are not yet available as the study is pre-results.
population_specificity: Caregivers of patients with ALS, primarily non-paid immediate family members.
effective_dosage: 9 weekly sessions for mindfulness-based stress reduction, 6 weekly sessions for building better caregivers.
study_duration: 9 weeks for mindfulness intervention, 6 weeks for caregiver training, with follow-up assessments at 12 weeks post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of a brief mindfulness intervention (10 minutes daily for 2 weeks) in reducing compulsive internet use (CIU) and symptoms of anxiety and depression compared to gradual-muscle-relaxation and a wait-list control group.
results_summary: The mindfulness intervention was equally effective as gradual-muscle-relaxation in reducing anxiety and depression but more effective in reducing CIU symptoms. The results suggest mindfulness could be a beneficial, easy-to-implement practice for individuals with early signs of CIU.
population_specificity: Adults showing initial signs of compulsive internet use (CIU).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the short-term effectiveness of a brief, one-on-one, telephone-adapted MBSR on psychological distress in PCI patients.
results_summary: The MBSR group showed significant reductions in anxiety, depression (HADS), and perceived stress (PSS) compared to the waitlist group, with effects mediated by increased mindfulness. The intervention was effective in improving psychological symptoms in PCI patients.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
effective_dosage: Three sessions of mindfulness intervention (specific duration per session not detailed).

study_goal: The study did not investigate Mindfulness; it focused on testing the acute effect of eating sweets on alcohol cravings in individuals with at-risk drinking.
results_summary: The study did not examine Mindfulness; it found no significant effect of eating sweets on alcohol cravings in the tested population.
population_specificity: Individuals with at-risk drinking (N = 150)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and mindfulness-based treatments in addressing emotion regulation difficulties in youth and young adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: The interventions, which included awareness of emotions, frustration tolerance, and emotion regulation skills, showed encouraging improvements in ER skills for individuals with high-functioning ASD. The inclusion of caregivers in group therapy was also noted as beneficial.
population_specificity: Youth and young adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), particularly those with high-functioning ASD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the types of mindfulness interventions used for healthcare professionals and their effectiveness in reducing stress and improving self-compassion and mindfulness.
results_summary: Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction Therapy (MBSR) was the most commonly used intervention, showing a reduction in stress and increased mindfulness among health professionals, though studies on self-compassion were scarce. The effect varied based on meditation practice duration.
population_specificity: Healthcare professionals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term effects of mindfulness practice, physical exercise, and cognitive training on serum BDNF levels in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that only cognitive training increased serum BDNF levels after 5 weeks, while mindfulness practice did not show a significant effect.
population_specificity: Healthy older individuals from the Boston area (US) and Växjö area (Sweden).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various interventions, including mindfulness, in increasing resilience among physicians and other health professionals.
results_summary: The study found mixed results regarding the effectiveness of mindfulness and other interventions in improving resilience, with some studies reporting significant improvements and others not. Group, online, and coaching interventions showed some effectiveness, but limitations like self-selection bias and lack of control groups were noted.
population_specificity: Physicians and a broader range of health professionals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mindfulness meditation and progressive relaxation in reducing chronic pain in older females with diabetes.
results_summary: Both mindfulness meditation (Group MM) and progressive relaxation (Group PM) showed significant reductions in chronic pain, as measured by the Brief Pain Inventory and Patient Global Impression of Change. The control meditation group (Group CM) was not mentioned to have significant effects.
population_specificity: Older females with diabetes experiencing chronic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness as an intervention to enhance social support among people with cardiovascular disease (CVD).
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness was one of several interventions tested, but few studies reported significant changes in social support measures. Caregiver-oriented strategies showed more promise than mindfulness alone.
population_specificity: People living with cardiovascular disease (CVD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and meta-analyze the effects of nature-based mindfulness interventions on psychological, physiological, and interpersonal outcomes.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant medium-sized effects of nature-based mindfulness interventions across psychological, physiological, and interpersonal outcomes, with consistent results in open trials and comparisons against non-active controls or similar non-nature interventions.
population_specificity: 2990 participants across 25 studies (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the health effects of mindfulness- and acceptance-based interventions (MBSR, MBCT, ACT) for fibromyalgia patients and explore their content and delivery components.
results_summary: The study found small to moderate effects favoring mindfulness- and acceptance-based interventions for pain, depression, anxiety, mindfulness, sleep quality, and health-related quality of life, though the results were uncertain due to study limitations and inconsistency.
population_specificity: Patients with fibromyalgia (vast majority women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different exercises, including mindfulness-based practices like Tai Chi and Baduanjin, on pain modulation and cognitive control pathways in knee osteoarthritis patients.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based exercises (Tai Chi and Baduanjin) improved pain scores, altered brain connectivity, and increased grey matter volume, with baseline brain connectivity predicting pain improvement. These effects were comparable to or better than stationary cycling.
population_specificity: 140 patients with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions in improving psychosocial outcomes for caregivers of individuals with ASD.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based interventions demonstrated a strong impact in improving caregiver psychosocial outcomes in pre-post comparisons, with overall small positive effects observed across various intervention approaches.
population_specificity: Caregivers of individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating a required mindfulness course for large groups of first-year medical students improved their mental health and quality of life.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the intervention (mindfulness) and control groups in mental health, quality of life, or mindfulness measures. No meaningful improvements were observed in the mindfulness group compared to controls.
population_specificity: First-year medical students at the Federal University of Juiz de Fora, Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) in reducing psychological distress and improving other health outcomes in cancer patients and survivors.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found small but statistically significant effects of MBIs on psychological distress and other symptoms like anxiety, depression, and fatigue, with larger effects observed in studies adhering to original MBI manuals, involving younger patients, or using passive controls. However, many effects were of small magnitude, suggesting a need for further optimization.
population_specificity: Cancer patients and survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of psychological and mind-body interventions, including mindfulness, in alleviating pain, psychological distress, sleep issues, and fatigue in women with endometriosis.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness and other PMB interventions show promise in reducing pain, anxiety, depression, stress, and fatigue in women with endometriosis, though no definitive conclusions could be drawn due to methodological limitations.
population_specificity: Women with endometriosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a positive emotion regulation (PER) group intervention, including mindfulness, for improving well-being in individuals with bipolar I disorder (BD) during symptom remission.
results_summary: Participants reported increases in mindfulness, reappraisal, and self-compassion post-intervention, but no significant differences in mania symptoms were detected. The intervention showed preliminary support for improving well-being in BD.
population_specificity: Individuals with bipolar I disorder (BD) in symptom remission (n=12 completed the study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (skills practiced on average 16 times a week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and mechanisms of a brief Mindfulness-Based Intervention (MBI) for improving personal recovery outcomes in individuals with bipolar disorder (BD).
results_summary: The study hypothesized that a brief MBI would improve personal recovery, mediated by enhanced emotion awareness, regulation, and illness acceptance, with differential benefits based on BD stage (early vs. late). Results are pending as this is a protocol.
population_specificity: Adults with bipolar disorder (BD) recruited from hospitals and community settings.
effective_dosage: Four sessions in total (specific duration per session not detailed).
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but assessments occur at baseline, post-intervention, and six-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the occurrence of sudden gains (SGs) in Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) and group cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) for social anxiety disorder (SAD) and assess their association with treatment outcomes.
results_summary: SGs occurred in 27% of participants in Study 2, with comparable rates in MBSR and group CBT. SGs were not associated with greater improvements in social anxiety during treatment in either condition.
population_specificity: Individuals with social anxiety disorder (SAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a case of malignant syphilis in an HIV-positive MSM patient.
results_summary: The study reported a case of malignant syphilis in an HIV-positive MSM patient, presenting with ulcerative lesions and systemic symptoms. Treatment with benzathine penicillin improved skin lesions and serologic titers.
population_specificity: HIV-positive MSM patient with syphilis co-infection.
effective_dosage: Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units once a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility of the WeTest+ mHealth intervention for providing continuous HIV services to high-risk MSM in China.
results_summary: The study found high engagement (96.4%) with the WeTest+ program, with most participants (92.9%) completing HIV self-testing and submitting results. Click-through rates were high (67.9%), and participants praised the program's content and user-centered features.
population_specificity: Men who have sex with men (MSM) in China, average age 27.6 years.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (behavioral intervention, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the population-level impact of PrEP, voluntary testing, and behavioral changes on HIV/AIDS spread and control in an MSM population using a mathematical model.
results_summary: The study found that PrEP adherence by 50% of the MSM population could avert 22% of new yearly HIV cases at peak, increasing to 50% with 80% coverage. Elimination prospects improve if high-risk individuals are no more than 15% more likely to acquire HIV than low-risk individuals and if undetected cases are detected promptly.
population_specificity: Men who have sex with men (MSM), stratified into low- and high-risk groups for HIV acquisition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine racial/ethnic differences in club drug use during sex and its association with sexual risk behaviors among MSM.
results_summary: The study found significant racial differences in club drug use and its association with condomless anal intercourse (CAI), with Asian/Pacific Islander and Latino MSM reporting higher rates of club drug use and increased odds of CAI when using drugs during sex.
population_specificity: Alcohol-using MSM in San Francisco (n=252).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the prevalence of Intimate Partner Violence (IPV) and its associations with behavioral and mental health outcomes among HIV-infected MSM in a Chinese context.
results_summary: The study found that 71.1% of HIV-infected MSM experienced IPV, which was significantly associated with sexual risk behavior, poor ART adherence, depression, anxiety, and suicidal ideation. Risk factors for IPV included abuse of certain drugs, disclosing HIV status to partners, and gay sexual orientation.
population_specificity: 294 HIV-infected men who have sex with men (MSM) in Jinan City, China.
study_duration: Data collected from June to December 2020 (cross-sectional study, no intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the motivators, facilitators, and barriers to oral and long-acting injectable PrEP use among Indian MSM.
results_summary: The study found that high perceived HIV risk motivated oral PrEP uptake, with most participants accessing it through non-profits. Participants reported high adherence but dissatisfaction with daily dosing and expressed interest in long-acting injectable PrEP, contingent on cost and availability.
population_specificity: Indian men who have sex with men (MSM), aged 18-40 (median 28).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore factors associated with willingness to initiate HIV testing and immediate treatment among men who have sex with men (MSM) in Nairobi and its environs.
results_summary: The study found that factors like never being tested for HIV, having unprotected anal sex, and belief in ARV efficacy were associated with higher likelihood of accepting the HIV test and treat initiative, while stigma and lifestyle concerns were barriers.
population_specificity: Men who have sex with men (MSM) aged 18-60 years in Nairobi and surrounding areas, reporting active engagement in anal or oral sex with men.
study_duration: Data collected between July 2018 and June 2019 (study duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of oral MSM with intra-articular injections (methylprednisolone and hyaluronic acid) in treating posttraumatic ankle osteoarthritis in an animal model.
results_summary: MSM showed better radiological outcomes compared to the control group (p < 0.001) but no significant histopathological difference (p = 0.466). The radiological progression of osteoarthritis was slowed in the MSM group, though functional range of motion did not differ significantly between groups.
population_specificity: Adult female Sprague-Dawley rats with posttraumatic ankle osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the needs of nurses to improve nursing care for HIV-positive men who have sex with men (MSM) in Indonesia.
results_summary: The study identified three key themes: effective therapeutic communication techniques for HIV-positive MSM, increasing nurses' skills and knowledge, and ensuring continuity of care. These improvements were expected to enhance the quality of nursing care and patient satisfaction.
population_specificity: HIV-positive men who have sex with men (MSM) in Indonesia and the nurses caring for them.
